docs.snippet: MEET THE OSCARS When Gary Cooper took the stage 66 years ago to accept an Oscar for portraying a reluctant war hero in ''Sergeant York,'' he had little to say. First he credited the person he had depicted on screen, then followed with an economica...
docs.lead_paragraph: MEET THE OSCARS When Gary Cooper took the stage 66 years ago to accept an Oscar for portraying a reluctant war hero in ''Sergeant York,'' he had little to say. First he credited the person he had depicted on screen, then followed with an economical 34 words: ''Shucks, I've been in the business 16 years and sometimes dreamed I might get one of these things. That's all I can say. Funny, when I was dreaming, I always made a good speech.'' Then he walked off the stage, accidentally leaving his trophy behind. Starting Friday at noon, you can try to one-up Mr. Cooper with an Oscar acceptance of your own. His statuette, the one that Thelma Schoonmaker was awarded last year for her editing of ''The Departed,'' and dozens of others have made their way to New York as part of the ''Meet the Oscars'' display at Times Square Studios, an exhibition that ends with a podium and the chance to pose with an Oscar.
docs.abstract: Exhibition of Oscars once owned by Gary Cooper and others will be part of display at Times Square Studios, which includes podium and chance to pose with Oscar; photo (S)

docs.snippet: 'READY FOR ACTION!' For a parent Sesame Street Live doesn't have quite the charm of ''Sesame Street'' on television. You lose the intimacy of the close-ups with the cheery characters, and the noise -- including the loud bangs of containers of conf...
docs.lead_paragraph: 'READY FOR ACTION!' For a parent Sesame Street Live doesn't have quite the charm of ''Sesame Street'' on television. You lose the intimacy of the close-ups with the cheery characters, and the noise -- including the loud bangs of containers of confetti bursting over the audience's heads -- may make you long for a remote control. But enough Oscar-like grouchiness. None of this seems to bother the energetic toddlers who throng Madison Square Garden every year for the 90-minute live extravaganza. The latest, ''Ready for Action!,'' begins with a topic dear to small children: superheroes. Grover, whose self-description as Super Grover is treated tongue-in-cheek on TV, has lost his ''superness''; when he tries to fly, he collapses in a heap (hilarious if you're under 6). Some of his fellow Muppets -- Telly, Zoe (and her pet rock), Elmo and Rosita -- step in as the Fabulous Five (above, flanking Grover), accepting assignments from the Big Cheese (a talking cheese wedge, of course) until Grover recovers.

docs.snippet: 9 P.M. (CBS) CELINE DION: THAT'S JUST THE WOMAN IN ME Ms. Dion, right, performs her first concert since ending her five-year run in Las Vegas in this hourlong special, taped at the Wiltern Theater in Los Angeles, featuring some of her hits, includ...
docs.lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (CBS) CELINE DION: THAT'S JUST THE WOMAN IN ME Ms. Dion, right, performs her first concert since ending her five-year run in Las Vegas in this hourlong special, taped at the Wiltern Theater in Los Angeles, featuring some of her hits, including ''Because You Loved Me,'' ''My Heart Will Go On'' and ''Taking Chances,'' and appearances by Josh Groban, Will.i.am and Joe Walsh. She'll also answer questions from V.I.P. guests like Corbin Bleu and David Foster. 8 P.M. (Ovation) LUST FOR LIFE (1956) Kirk Douglas plays Vincent van Gogh in this drama from Vincente Minnelli, based on the fictionalized biography by Irving Stone about van Gogh's tortured life. Anthony Quinn won his second Oscar for best supporting actor for his portrayal of Paul Gauguin.

docs.snippet: The "Juno" screenwriter is a lock, right? Maybe not, says one ninny, who smells a rat....
docs.lead_paragraph: Some of you have already started filling in your ballots for the Oscar pool, beginning with the easy ones, like Diablo Cody for original screenplay. Sasha Stones takes a hard look and smells a rat than might sneak up on her.
docs.abstract: The "Juno" screenwriter is a lock, right? Maybe not, says one ninny, who smells a rat.
